member.name: T:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.RgbConversion
member.summary: Available conversion modes from Bayer patterns to RGB images.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.RgbConversion.Linear
member.summary: This method offers the highest accuracy but also the slowest speed. Interpolation of the nearest pixels is used to calculate the two unknown color values for each position. Depending on the position of the pixel either two or four pixels are used for the interpolation. In this mode full spatial resolution is maintained.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.RgbConversion.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: This method offers the fastest speed for a full resolution image, but the color accuracy is not as high as the Linear method. The color from a neighbor pixel is used for the two unknown color values. This makes the conversion faster because there is no need for interpolation. In this method full spatial resolution is maintained.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.RgbConversion.HalfResolution
member.summary: This method is provided primarily for display. This method creates an RGB image with half the height and half the width of the source image, the color accuracy is the same as the NearestNeighbor method but half the spacial accuracy is lost. If the user needs a fast display for focusing or setup of the camera, then this method will allow higher frame rates on a suitable PC.

member.summary: 2D curve functions.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Curve.Resample(Stemmer.Cvb.Point2Dd[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Resamples a 2-dimensional curve via linear interpolation assuming that the "speed" of the time mapping is constant.
member.remarks: The points have to be ordered by ascending x coordinates.
member.exception: When is null.
When is empty.
When is > 1.
When an error during resampling occurs.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Curve.IntersectWithLine(Stemmer.Cvb.Point2Dd[],Stemmer.Cvb.Geometry2D.Line)
member.summary:
Intersects a 2D curve with a line.
The line is defined by the hessian normal form: normal * x = d, with normal = 1 and d > 0.
member.remarks: The points have to be ordered by ascending x coordinates.
member.exception: When is null.
When is empty.
When an error during intersecting occurs.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Curve.CalculateSignedDifferences(Stemmer.Cvb.Point2Dd[],Stemmer.Cvb.Point2Dd[])
member.summary: Calculates signed differences along the y axis of given points to curve (Curve - Points).
member.remarks: The points have to be ordered by ascending x coordinates.
member.exception: When or is null.
When contains less than 2 points or contains less than 1 point.
When an error during calculation occurs.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Curve.Align(Stemmer.Cvb.Point2Dd[],Stemmer.Cvb.Point2Dd[],Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.AlignmentSettings)
member.summary:
Aligns two 2D curves via an iterative closest point method considering consensus correspondence for better shape alignment.
The method used here is a version of the ICP (closest iterative point) method. It uses a consensus metric to find the correspondence between points to stabilize the iterations needed in the alignment method. It supports only rigid transformations for the alignment. If not enough points within a given consens are found a classical ICP step is perfomed by finding corresponences soley based on nearest neighbours without any feasibility check.
member.exception: When or is null.
When or is empty.
When an error during alignment occurs.

member.name: T:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
The namespace and assembly Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation holds all classes and definitions that expose functionality of the Common Vision Blox Foundation Package. The Foundation Package comprises the following DLLs:
Arithmetic.dll
etBayerToRGB.dll
CVCEdge.dll
CVFoundation.dll
DrawGraph.dll (not covered here)
LightMeter.dll
TextOut.dll
ZXBarcode.dll
Note that a valid Common Vision Blox Foundation Package license is required to use this functionality unrestricted. If no license is available, function-specific restrictions apply.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Polarization.Pattern.BayerGreenBlue
member.summary:
A flag to add if the polarization plane is additionally color-encoded with a bayer pattern. Only supported with . The bayer-pattern is assumed to be:
GG BB
GG BB
RR GG
RR GG
Therefore a polarization pattern group is \em within one color group.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Polarization.ConvertToPlanes(Stemmer.Cvb.Image,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Polarization.Pattern,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Polarization.ImageResolution)
member.summary: Extracts the four polarization angles from a raw image to a four plane image.
member.remarks:
From a raw polarization image this function extracts the polarization angles to outImage. The returned image holds the polarization data as 4 planes sorted by increasing angle: 0, 45, 90, 135
The expected pattern of the raw image with for example is a 2x2 pattern with: Top-left: 90, Top-right: 45, Bottom-left: 135, Bottom-right: 0.
If resolution is set to CVPOL_RESOLUTION_FULL the image is interpolated and has the same size as rawImage, otherwise it will be half the size.
member.param: Input image with raw polarization data.
Indicates in which pattern the polarization angles are ordered in \a rawImage.
Resolution of outImage. If set to CVPOL_RESOLUTION_FULL the image is interpolated and will equal the size of rawImage, otherwise it will be half the size.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Polarization.CalculateStokesImage(Stemmer.Cvb.Image)
member.summary: From an extracted a new image is returned with the Stokes 0 to 2 as planes.
member.remarks: From a extracted polarization image the three first Stokes are calculated and returned in outImage. Stokes 0 is calculated as (0 + 45 + 90 + 135) * 0.25. The index of the plane represents the Stokes' number.
member.param: Input image with extracted polarization data. Usually from .

member.summary: From an extracted a new image is returned with the Stokes 0 as content.
member.remarks: From an extracted polarization image Stokes 0 is calculated and returned in outImage. Stokes 0 is calculated as (0 + 45 + 90 + 135) * 0.25.
member.param: Input image with extracted polarization data. Usually from .
member.returns: The resulting image with one plane.

member.summary: From an extracted the minimum reflection image is calculated and returned.
member.remarks: The minimum reflection image is calculated by taking the minimum value of all the polarization angles that are contained in the input image.

member.name: T:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CorrelationMethod
member.summary: Correlation calculation methods.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CorrelationMethod.SumOfSquareDistances
member.summary: Normalized sum of square Distances.
member.remarks: Strictly speaking, this is not a correlation, but the inverse of it (i.e. when looking at the resulting accumulator, dark spots indicate a close match between the image and the template, whereas bright areas indicate image regions, where there is little to no similarity between image and template).

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CorrelationMethod.CorrelationCoefficients
member.summary: Calculate the normalized correlation coefficients between image and template.
member.remarks: These can be considered a measure of similarity between the input image and the template. Wherever the correlation coefficient is high (maximum is 1.0), image and template are very similar. Where the correlation coefficient approaches zero, the similarities vanish.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CorrelationMethod.CrossCorrelation
member.summary: Calculate the cross correlations between image and template.

member.name: T:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Correlation
member.summary: Collection of functions that calculate different kinds of correlation values.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Correlation.Calculate(Stemmer.Cvb.ImagePlane,Stemmer.Cvb.ImagePlane,Stemmer.Cvb.Rect,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CorrelationMethod)
member.summary: Calculate the correlation between an and a using a selectable calculation .

remarks.para: The result of the correlation will be an accumulator image with 32 bit floating point pixels containing the results.
Note that the accumulator will be smaller than the input , the difference being width (or height) of the - 1. The template will be anchored at its central pixel (fractional positions cut off).

In other words: The pixel (0, 0) of the accumulator corresponds to image position (int)(template width / 2, template height / 2) and its value will be a representation of the correlation between the input image and the template, centered around this very pixel.

member.param: Image plane to perform the correlation on.
Template plane to perform the correlation with.
Area of interest to perform the correlation on.
member.exception: If the to work on has already been disposed.
Thrown if is unknown.

member.exception: If the input is null
If the input has already been disposed

member.name: T:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftImage
member.summary: Cvb Image representation in the Fourier domain.

remarks.para: This image type is not a full-fledged frequency-domain representation of the image data - it makes use of the symmetries induced by the fact that the source data we are working on is practically always real-valued, which allows for a more compact storage and faster computation of the frequency domain operations.

However, this also means that it is not possible to simply manipulate the amplitude and phase information in the frequency domain with this image type. You should think of it as a buffer rather than a real image (although it is in fact possible to display it).

member.name: T:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftNormalization
member.summary: Normalization modes that can be applied when calculating the Fourier transform or its inverse.

remarks.para: Effectively this is the factor before the transformation integral.
Typically the same factor should be applied in forward and inverse transform, otherwise the absolute pixel values of a transformation round trip will differ from the original pixel values.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftNormalization.Forward
member.summary: Apply a factor 1/N in forward transformation, but not in inverse transformation.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftNormalization.Inverse
member.summary: Apply a factor 1/N in the inverse transformation but not in forward transformation.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftNormalization.Sqrt
member.summary: Apply a factor 1/sqrt(N) in inverse and forward transformation alike.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftNormalization.None
member.summary: No or unknown normalization.

member.name: T:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftWindow
member.summary: Window function to apply when calculating a Fourier transform.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftWindow.None
member.summary: Do not apply a Window function.
member.remarks: This will allow Fourier transformation artifacts caused by the abrupt ending of the image data at the image borders to creep into the Fourier transform; these artifacts will become visible as high frequency oscillations in the back transformed image.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftWindow.Hamming
member.summary: Apply a Hamming window function.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftWindow.Bartlett
member.summary: Apply a Bartlett window function.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftWindow.SeparateBartlett
member.summary: Apply a Bartlett window function successively to individual rows and columns of the image.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Fft.Filter.CreateBandStop(Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.FftImage,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Create a Fourier space representation of a band stop filter with a default width of 10%.
member.remarks: Such a filter can be applied to an image by multiplying the image's Fourier transform with this filter image and then transforming the result back to Cartesian space.

param.name: img
param.para: Image to apply the filter on.
This input image will not directly be processed - it is required to determine the necessary size of the result image only.

member.param: Lower cutoff position of the filter relative to the frequency range (range [0...1]).
Upper cutoff position of the filter relative to the frequency range (range [0...1]).

member.summary: This function calculates (and writes into the output image) the distance to the closest pixel in the source image with the value zero for all nonzero pixels in the input image. Distance is calculated approximatively using a set of principal distances, that is governed by the MaskSize parameter and the distance norm.
member.param: Image plane on which to calculate.
Mask size to use for the approximator (only 3x3 and 5x5 are acceptable)
Distance calculation norm to be used

member.remarks: Both images should be identical in size. However, if they are not, the smallest common rectangle (located at the top left pixel) of both images will be the size of the result image. Both input images should have identical dimensions (either 1 or 3 planes per image) and identical data types.
member.param: Image containing the threshold values for the pixels of the input .
member.exception: If the input or is null.
If the input or has already been disposed.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Threshold.Dynamic(Stemmer.Cvb.Image,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This function performs dynamic thresholding on the input image with the norm.

remarks.para: Dynamic thresholding works such that for each pixel of the input image, the average gray value over a mask with given size (centered around the pixel in question) is calculated. If the difference between this average and the pixel that is currently being looked at is above the specified threshold, then the corresponding pixel in the output image is set to white, otherwise it is black.
This function is particularly useful when dealing with images that have a non-uniform illumination.

param.name: windowSize
param.para: Window size to be for calculating the dynamic threshold.
Bigger window sizes will lead to higher processing times.

member.exception: If the input is null
If the input has already been disposed

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Threshold.Dynamic(Stemmer.Cvb.Image,System.Int32,System.Int32,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.DynamicThresholdNorm)
member.summary: This function performs dynamic thresholding on the input image.

remarks.para: Dynamic thresholding works by calculating the average gray value over a mask with given size(centered around the pixel in question) for each input pixel. If the difference between this average and the pixel, that is currently being looked at, is above the specified threshold, then the corresponding pixel in the output image is set to white, otherwise it is black.
This function is particularly useful, when dealing with images, that have a non-uniform illumination.

param.name: windowSize
param.para: Window size to calculate the dynamic threshold.
Bigger window sizes will lead to higher processing times.

member.exception: If the input is null
If the input has already been disposed

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Filter.Canny(Stemmer.Cvb.ImagePlane,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.EdgeFilter,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Edge filter using the Canny algorithm.
member.remarks:
The algorithm uses three stages:
is differentiated in x and y direction using the . From the two derivatives the direction and magnitude is computed.
The directional information is simplified and then the local maximum along an edge contour is determined that lies above the .
The contours are then traced starting from the local maximum using hysteresis thresholding with the to counter broken edges.
member.param: Edge filter method to be used.
Upper threshold for edge detection and hysteresis thresholding.
member.exception: If the input has already been disposed.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.Filter.Wiener(Stemmer.Cvb.Image,Stemmer.Cvb.Size2D)
member.summary: This function performs adaptive filtering of an image degraded by constant power additive noise.

remarks.para: For each pixel of the input image, the function determines the local image mean and variance in the rectangular neighborhood (mask) defined by . The deviation from the local average is then diminished according to the local variance and the noise threshold parameters. The noise threshold parameter may be zero, in which case the function tries to determine itself what local noise threshold to apply. This normally yields the best results.
Mask offset is automatically set to the center of the image.

member.exception: If the input is null
If the input has already been disposed

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.NonLinearTransformation.FromCalibrationPattern(Stemmer.Cvb.ImagePlane,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CalibrationPatternStyle,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CalibrationPatternContrast,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Double@)
member.summary: Create a new transformation object by automatically extracting the pixel lists required for creating a object.

remarks.para: The image given to this method needs to contain a calibration pattern as generated by the method : A regularly spaced matrix of dots, the distance between the dots in x- and y-direction should be 2.5 times the diameter of the dots, if an asymmetric pattern was used, the bigger dots should have 2.5 times the area of the smaller dots (meaning that their radius is sqrt(2.5) times the radius of the small dots).
To avoid misunderstandings and complications in the interpretation of the image content, it is recommended to use a default coordinate system on the input image.

member.param: Calibration pattern style visible in the image. (see )
Selects whether the image shows or dots.

param.name: gridSpacing
param.para: Spacing of the calibration dot grid in the target image.
Defines the distance of the points that will end up in the transformed pixels.

param.name: minContrast
param.para: Minimum gray value contrast between the object and the background of the calibration target pattern.

Value to be set depends on the quality of the image taken from the pattern, but in a typical situation this contrast should not drop below 64 gray values, otherwise it might become difficult to extract the calibration points.

param.name: maxRatio
param.para: Maximum ratio between the biggest and the smallest calibration dot.

This value will be used to identify outliers when looking for calibration dots. It should be set high enough to allow for the area variations to be expected due to perspective distortions and small enough to eliminate the candidates that are either too big or too small to be valid calibration pattern dots.

Typically, values of about 3.0 to 5.0 are big enough - even if there is notable perspective distortion visible in the images. If an asymmetric calibration pattern has been selected, the ratio used for calculation will be adapted accordingly.

member.param: Polynomial order of the transformation to be generated.

param.name: quality
param.para: Quality feedback.
Derived by correlating the application of the resulting transformation to the set of the calibration pattern.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.NonLinearTransformation.FromCalibrationPattern(Stemmer.Cvb.ImagePlane,Stemmer.Cvb.Area2D,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CalibrationPatternStyle,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CalibrationPatternContrast,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Double@)
member.summary: Create a new transformation object by automatically extracting the pixel lists required for creating a object.

remarks.para: The image given to this method needs to contain a calibration pattern as generated by the method : A regularly spaced matrix of dots, the distance between the dots in x- and y-direction should be 2.5 times the diameter of the dots, if an asymmetric pattern was used, the bigger dots should have 2.5 times the area of the smaller dots (meaning that their radius is sqrt(2.5) times the radius of the small dots).

Note that, although the area of interest is given as a here (and in the processing of the Area2D the image's coordinate system will be respected), the actual output of this method uses ! This seemingly inconsistent mix in this case is in fact useful, because a Area2D will better capture the actual location of a calibration pattern, especially if the image has been rotated, than a style area of interest. But the calibration functions working on the output of ExtractCalibrationLists usually assume that the pixel lists are given in pixel coordinates.
To avoid misunderstandings and complications in the interpretation of the image content, it is recommended to use a default coordinate system on the input image.

member.name: T:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CalibrationPattern
member.summary: Methods for CVB calibration pattern handling.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CalibrationPattern.Create(Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CalibrationPatternStyle,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.CalibrationPatternContrast,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a user-definable calibration pattern.

remarks.para: The calibration pattern will consist of a regular spaced matrix of dots, the size of which will be determined by the input parameters. The distance between the dots in x- and y-direction will be 2.5 times the diameter of the dots.
If an asymmetric pattern was selected, the bigger dots will have 2.5 times the area of the smaller dots (meaning that their radius is sqrt(2.5) times the radius of the small dots).

member.param: Selects whether to use white on black or black on white dots (see ).
Width of the output image in pixels.
Height of the output image in pixels.
Number of dot columns in the image.
Number of dot rows in the image.

member.summary: Create a user-definable calibration pattern suitable for printing on a sheet of paper. The calibration pattern will consist of a regularly spaced matrix of dots, the size of which will be determined by the input parameters. The size of the pattern image will be suitable for printing it on an piece of paper defined by the parameter. The calibration pattern will consist of a regular rectangular grid of dots. The distance between the dots in x- and y-direction will be 2.5 times the diameter of the dots. If an asymmetric pattern was selected, the bigger dots will have 2.5 times the area of the smaller dots (meaning that their radius is sqrt(2.5) times the radius of the small dots).
member.param: Selects whether to use white on black or black on white dots (see ).
Number of dot columns in the image.
Number of dot rows in the image.

param.name: horizontalBorder
param.para: Horizontal borders to be applied (in inches).

This value should match the setting that is going to be used for printing the resulting image. Must not be negative. The meaning of horizontal refers to the paper size definition and is independent of the setting.

param.name: verticalBorder
param.para: Vertical borders to be applied (in inches).

This value should match the setting that is going to be used for printing the resulting image. Must not be negative. The meaning of vertical refers to the paper size definition and is independent of the setting.

param.name: dpi
param.para: Dot density to be used (in dots per inch).
It usually makes sense to set this parameter to the printer's physical dot density or half or quarter of that. Minimum value is 150.

The image given to this method needs to contain a calibration pattern as generated by the method : A regularly spaced matrix of dots, the distance between the dots in x- and y-direction should be 2.5 times the diameter of the dots, if an asymmetric pattern was used, the bigger dots should have 2.5 times the area of the smaller dots (meaning that their radius is sqrt(2.5) times the radius of the small dots).

Note that, although the area of interest is given as a here (and in the processing of the Area2D the image's coordinate system will be respected), the actual output of this method uses ! This seemingly inconsistent mix in this case is in fact useful, because a Area2D will better capture the actual location of a calibration pattern, especially if the image has been rotated, than a style area of interest. But the calibration functions usually assume that the pixel lists are given in pixel coordinates.
To avoid misunderstandings and complications in the interpretation of the image content, it is recommended to use a default coordinate system on the input image.

member.param: Area of interest in which to look for the calibration pattern's dots.
Calibration pattern style visible in the image. (see )
Selects whether the image shows or dots.

param.name: gridSpacing
param.para: Spacing of the calibration dot grid in the target image.
Defines the distance of the points that will end up in the list.

param.name: minContrast
param.para: Minimum gray value contrast between the object and the background of the calibration target pattern.

Value to be set depends on the quality of the image taken from the pattern, but in a typical situation this contrast should not drop below 64 gray values, otherwise it might become difficult to extract the calibration points.

param.name: maxRatio
param.para: Maximum ratio between the biggest and the smallest calibration dot.

This value will be used to identify outliers when looking for calibration dots. It should be set high enough to allow for the area variations to be expected due to perspective distortions and small enough to eliminate the candidates that are either too big or too small to be valid calibration pattern dots.

Typically, values of about 3.0 to 5.0 are big enough - even if there is notable perspective distortion visible in the images. If an asymmetric calibration pattern has been selected, the ratio used for calculation will be adapted accordingly.

member.param: Point list to contain the locations of the calibration dots in the input image in pixel coordinates.
Pixel list to contain the appropriate locations of the calibration dots in the target image of the calibration.

member.name: T:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.ZxBarcodeBinarizationMode
member.summary: Binarization modes usable with the methods of the static class.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.ZxBarcodeBinarizationMode.Histogram
member.summary: Binarization mode in which a global threshold is being applied to the image. The global threshold is automatically calculated based on the area of interest's histogram. This binarization mode is not as flexible as in that it cannot cope with inhomogeneous illumination. However the processing time of the histogram based binarization is much lower than that of the hybrid binarization mode.

member.name: F:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.ZxBarcodeBinarizationMode.Hybrid
member.summary: Binarization mode that uses a local thresholding algorithm. The Hybrid binarization mode yields much better result than the global histogram mode if the illumination in the image is not homogeneous, but it also requires more CPU time.

member.name: M:Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.ZxBarcode.Binarize(Stemmer.Cvb.ImagePlane,Stemmer.Cvb.Rect,Stemmer.Cvb.Foundation.ZxBarcodeBinarizationMode)
member.summary:
This function applies the binarization that the function
/ is going to use internally. This can be useful for judging whether which binarization will be good enough for reading the code(s). Note that it is not necessary to apply binarization to an image prior Read/ReadMultiple as these methods will always automatically binarize the image passed to it.

remarks.para: Please note that this function is not guaranteed to be thread-safe and we strongly advise against calling it simultaneously from different threads.

This function uses the zxing-cpp library (see https://github.com/glassechidna/zxing-cpp). zxing-cpp is a fork of the zxing project and is published under the Apache v2.0 license which requires applications and libraries that make use of this function to declare in their license information that they are using the zxing-cpp library. This may be done e.g. by adding a link to the zxing-cpp project page and the Apache v2.0 license terms (https://github.com/glassechidna/zxing-cpp/blob/master/COPYING) e.g. to a "Help" or "About" screen. In Common Vision Blox the respective links have been added to the document \a OpenSourceLicenses.chm.

member.param: Input plane to work on. The plane needs to have 8 bits per pixel, otherwise an error will be returned. Note that ZXing Barcode can only process luminance information. If the input image uses a color format, either select a suitable plane or convert it to luminance information before processing it in ZXBarcode.
Area of interest to be binarized.
Selects the binarization algorithm to use. see for eligible values.
member.exception: if the image to which the input plane belongs has already been disposed
if the input plane does not have 8 bits per pixel unsigned integer format or if the is invalid.

member.summary: Read a bar code in an image. Unlike its counterpart, , this function only reads one code. For an image with more than one code of the selected symbology it is undefined which code will be returned.

remarks.para: Please note that this function is not guaranteed to be thread-safe and we strongly advise against calling it simultaneously from different threads.

When calling this function without a valid Common Vision Blox Foundation Package license, the results returned by the function call will be partly garbled: Any '0' in the result will be replaced by a '5' and any 'e' or 'E' will be replaced by an 'x' or 'X' respectively.

Area of interest to be searched for a readable code.
Selects the binarization algorithm to use. see for eligible values.
Thoroughness to be applied when searching for codes. See for possible values.

Flags that provide a hint at what barcode formats are to be expected in the image. This hint does not limit the reading of codes - if the hint points toward e.g. Code 128 and/or QR codes and the image contains a DataMatrix code, the code will be read nevertheless. However, providing the reader with the information what code(s) might be visible in the image may speed up reading slightly. This value can be a combination of the flags in the enumeration if more than one symbology is to be expected (remember, however, that even if multiple symbologies were specified, this function will still read one code; for reading multiple codes please use .
member.exception: if the image to which the input plane belongs has already been disposed
if the input plane does not have 8 bits per pixel unsigned integer format or if the is invalid.
member.returns: Single read result if a code has been read successfully, otherwise null.
